user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_dev_close:
```c
static void metal_linux_dev_close(struct metal_bus *bus,
				  struct metal_device *device)
{
	struct linux_device *ldev = to_linux_device(device);
	struct linux_bus *lbus = to_linux_bus(bus);

	ldev->ldrv->dev_close(lbus, ldev);
	metal_list_del(&device->node);
	free(ldev);
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
metal_list_del(&device->node);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: Not violated. The fragment calls metal_list_del(&device->node), which is a linked-list operation and does not invoke any of the <string.h> functions listed in MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 (memcpy/memmove/memset/memcmp/strcpy/strncpy/strcat/strncat/strlen/strspn). Therefore this call, as shown, does not violate Rule 21.17. (Note: if the implementation of metal_list_del internally used any of those string functions incorrectly and caused out-of-bounds accesses, that internal implementation would violate the rule, but no such use is visible in the provided fragment.)
